file.content:
# Apple Notes and Reminders Databases Overview

## Database Locations

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[macOS User Data] --> B[Notes Database]
    A --> C[Calendar/Reminders Database]
    
    B --> D[~/Library/Containers/com.apple.Notes/Data/Library/Notes/]
    B --> E[NotesV7.storedata and related files]
    
    C --> F[~/Library/Group Containers/group.com.apple.calendar/]
    C --> G[Calendar.sqlitedb]
```

## Database Architecture Overview

```mermaid
flowchart LR
    subgraph "Apple Notes"
        N1[ZNOTE\nMetadata about notes] --- N2[ZNOTEBODY\nHTML content]
        N1 --- N3[ZATTACHMENT\nFiles & images]
        N4[ZFOLDER\nNote folders] --- N1
        N5[ZACCOUNT\nSync accounts] --- N4
    end
    
    subgraph "Apple Reminders/Calendar"
        R1[Calendar\nReminder lists] --- R2[CalendarItem\nReminders & events]
        R2 --- R3[Alarm\nReminder alerts]
        R2 --- R4[Recurrence\nRepeat patterns]
        R2 --- R5[Attachment\nFiles & links]
    end
```

## Data Storage Model

Both databases use SQLite with a similar architecture:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Core Tables] --> B[Main data entities]
    A --> C[Relationship tables]
    A --> D[Support/metadata tables]
    
    E[Storage Files] --> F[Main .storedata/.sqlitedb file]
    E --> G[WAL files\nWrite-ahead logging]
    E --> H[SHM files\nShared memory]
```

## How to Access the Data

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Backup Files] --> B{Access Method}
    
    B --> C[Direct SQLite Queries]
    B --> D[Python with sqlite3]
    B --> E[Export Scripts]
    
    C --> F[Query core tables\nwith JOIN statements]
    D --> G[Object mapping\nto app entities]
    E --> H[Convert to JSON, XML,\nor Markdown]
```

## Backup Approach

The included `backup-data.sh` script backs up these databases using the following approach:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Script as backup-data.sh
    participant System as File System
    
    User->>Script: Execute script
    Script->>System: Create data directory
    Script->>System: Copy Notes database files
    Note over Script,System: NotesV7.storedata and related files
    Script->>System: Copy Calendar database file
    Note over Script,System: Calendar.sqlitedb
    Script->>User: Show confirmation
```

These databases contain all your notes and reminders data, allowing for backup, analysis, or export via custom tools.

1	# Apple Notes Database Schema
     2	
     3	The Apple Notes database uses a SQLite structure with several key tables that manage notes, their content, folders, and attachments.
     4	
     5	## Core Tables Relationship Diagram
     6	
     7	```mermaid
     8	erDiagram
     9	    ZNOTE ||--o{ ZNOTEBODY : "has content"
    10	    ZNOTE ||--o{ ZATTACHMENT : "has attachments"
    11	    ZFOLDER ||--o{ ZNOTE : "contains"
    12	    ZACCOUNT ||--o{ ZFOLDER : "has folders"
    13	    
    14	    ZNOTE {
    15	        int Z_PK
    16	        int ZBODY
    17	        int ZFOLDER
    18	        timestamp ZDATECREATED
    19	        timestamp ZDATEEDITED
    20	        string ZTITLE
    21	        blob ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID
    22	    }
    23	    
    24	    ZNOTEBODY {
    25	        int Z_PK
    26	        int ZNOTE
    27	        string ZHTMLSTRING
    28	    }
    29	    
    30	    ZFOLDER {
    31	        int Z_PK
    32	        int ZPARENT
    33	        int ZACCOUNT
    34	        string ZNAME
    35	    }
    36	    
    37	    ZATTACHMENT {
    38	        int Z_PK
    39	        int ZNOTE
    40	        string ZCONTENTID
    41	        blob ZFILEURL
    42	    }
    43	    
    44	    ZACCOUNT {
    45	        int Z_PK
    46	        string ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION
    47	        string ZEMAILADDRESS
    48	    }
    49	```
    50	
    51	## Data Flow in Notes
    52	
    53	```mermaid
    54	graph TD
    55	    A[User creates note] --> B[ZNOTE record created]
    56	    B --> C[ZNOTEBODY record stores content]
    57	    B --> D[ZFOLDER links to note]
    58	    A --> E[User adds attachment]
    59	    E --> F[ZATTACHMENT record created]
    60	    F --> B
    61	```
    62	
    63	## Key Relationships
    64	
    65	- **ZNOTE to ZNOTEBODY**: One-to-one relationship - each note has one body record that contains the HTML content
    66	- **ZNOTE to ZFOLDER**: Many-to-one relationship - many notes can be in a single folder
    67	- **ZFOLDER to ZFOLDER**: Self-referencing relationship through ZPARENT field - creates folder hierarchy
    68	- **ZNOTE to ZATTACHMENT**: One-to-many relationship - a note can have multiple attachments
    69	- **ZACCOUNT to ZFOLDER**: One-to-many relationship - an account can have multiple folders
    70	
    71	This database design allows Apple Notes to efficiently store and organize notes with rich content across multiple devices and accounts.

1	# Apple Reminders Database Schema
     2	
     3	The Apple Reminders system stores its data within the Calendar database (Calendar.sqlitedb). This database handles both calendar events and reminders with a shared set of tables.
     4	
     5	## Core Tables Relationship Diagram
     6	
     7	```mermaid
     8	erDiagram
     9	    Calendar ||--o{ CalendarItem : "contains"
    10	    CalendarItem ||--o{ Alarm : "has alarms"
    11	    CalendarItem ||--o{ Recurrence : "has recurrence"
    12	    CalendarItem ||--o{ Participant : "has participants"
    13	    CalendarItem ||--o{ Attachment : "has attachments"
    14	    
    15	    Calendar {
    16	        int ROWID
    17	        string title
    18	        int color
    19	        int type
    20	        int external_id
    21	    }
    22	    
    23	    CalendarItem {
    24	        int ROWID
    25	        string summary
    26	        string description
    27	        real start_date
    28	        real end_date
    29	        int calendar_id
    30	        real due_date
    31	        int priority
    32	        real completion_date
    33	        real creation_date
    34	        int entity_type
    35	        int hidden
    36	    }
    37	    
    38	    Alarm {
    39	        int ROWID
    40	        int calendaritem_owner_id
    41	        real fire_date
    42	        int type
    43	    }
    44	    
    45	    Recurrence {
    46	        int ROWID
    47	        int owner_id
    48	        int frequency
    49	        int interval
    50	        int end_date_type
    51	    }
    52	    
    53	    Attachment {
    54	        int ROWID
    55	        int owner_id
    56	        string filename
    57	        blob data
    58	    }
    59	    
    60	    Participant {
    61	        int ROWID
    62	        int owner_id
    63	        int type
    64	        string name
    65	        string email
    66	    }
    67	```
    68	
    69	## Distinguishing Reminders from Calendar Events
    70	
    71	In the CalendarItem table, reminders and calendar events are differentiated by the `entity_type` field:
    72	
    73	```mermaid
    74	graph TD
    75	    A[CalendarItem] --> B{entity_type}
    76	    B -->|Calendar Event| C[Regular events]
    77	    B -->|Reminder| D[Tasks/Reminders]
    78	```
    79	
    80	## Key Data Flows
    81	
    82	```mermaid
    83	graph TD
    84	    A[User creates reminder] --> B[CalendarItem created with reminder entity_type]
    85	    B --> C[Set due_date and priority]
    86	    B --> D[User adds alarm/alert]
    87	    D --> E[Alarm record created]
    88	    B --> F[User sets repeat pattern]
    89	    F --> G[Recurrence record created]
    90	    B --> H[User marks complete]
    91	    H --> I[completion_date set]
    92	```
    93	
    94	## Key Fields for Reminders
    95	
    96	- **summary**: The title of the reminder
    97	- **description**: Details or notes about the reminder
    98	- **due_date**: When the reminder is due
    99	- **priority**: The priority level (high, medium, low)
   100	- **completion_date**: When the reminder was marked as completed (null if not completed)
   101	- **entity_type**: Identifies this as a reminder rather than a calendar event
   102	- **calendar_id**: Which reminder list this belongs to (reminder lists are stored as Calendar records)
   103	
   104	This shared database design allows Apple to efficiently integrate reminders with calendar functionality while maintaining separate views in the user interface.

file.content:
# Apple Notes Database Schema

The Apple Notes database uses a SQLite structure with several key tables that manage notes, their content, folders, and attachments.

## Core Tables Relationship Diagram

```mermaid
erDiagram
    ZNOTE ||--o{ ZNOTEBODY : "has content"
    ZNOTE ||--o{ ZATTACHMENT : "has attachments"
    ZFOLDER ||--o{ ZNOTE : "contains"
    ZACCOUNT ||--o{ ZFOLDER : "has folders"
    
    ZNOTE {
        int Z_PK
        int ZBODY
        int ZFOLDER
        timestamp ZDATECREATED
        timestamp ZDATEEDITED
        string ZTITLE
        blob ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID
    }
    
    ZNOTEBODY {
        int Z_PK
        int ZNOTE
        string ZHTMLSTRING
    }
    
    ZFOLDER {
        int Z_PK
        int ZPARENT
        int ZACCOUNT
        string ZNAME
    }
    
    ZATTACHMENT {
        int Z_PK
        int ZNOTE
        string ZCONTENTID
        blob ZFILEURL
    }
    
    ZACCOUNT {
        int Z_PK
        string ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION
        string ZEMAILADDRESS
    }
```

## Data Flow in Notes

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[User creates note] --> B[ZNOTE record created]
    B --> C[ZNOTEBODY record stores content]
    B --> D[ZFOLDER links to note]
    A --> E[User adds attachment]
    E --> F[ZATTACHMENT record created]
    F --> B
```

## Key Relationships

- **ZNOTE to ZNOTEBODY**: One-to-one relationship - each note has one body record that contains the HTML content
- **ZNOTE to ZFOLDER**: Many-to-one relationship - many notes can be in a single folder
- **ZFOLDER to ZFOLDER**: Self-referencing relationship through ZPARENT field - creates folder hierarchy
- **ZNOTE to ZATTACHMENT**: One-to-many relationship - a note can have multiple attachments
- **ZACCOUNT to ZFOLDER**: One-to-many relationship - an account can have multiple folders

This database design allows Apple Notes to efficiently store and organize notes with rich content across multiple devices and accounts.

file.content:
# Apple Reminders Database Schema

The Apple Reminders system stores its data within the Calendar database (Calendar.sqlitedb). This database handles both calendar events and reminders with a shared set of tables.

## Core Tables Relationship Diagram

```mermaid
erDiagram
    Calendar ||--o{ CalendarItem : "contains"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Alarm : "has alarms"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Recurrence : "has recurrence"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Participant : "has participants"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Attachment : "has attachments"
    
    Calendar {
        int ROWID
        string title
        int color
        int type
        int external_id
    }
    
    CalendarItem {
        int ROWID
        string summary
        string description
        real start_date
        real end_date
        int calendar_id
        real due_date
        int priority
        real completion_date
        real creation_date
        int entity_type
        int hidden
    }
    
    Alarm {
        int ROWID
        int calendaritem_owner_id
        real fire_date
        int type
    }
    
    Recurrence {
        int ROWID
        int owner_id
        int frequency
        int interval
        int end_date_type
    }
    
    Attachment {
        int ROWID
        int owner_id
        string filename
        blob data
    }
    
    Participant {
        int ROWID
        int owner_id
        int type
        string name
        string email
    }
```

## Distinguishing Reminders from Calendar Events

In the CalendarItem table, reminders and calendar events are differentiated by the `entity_type` field:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[CalendarItem] --> B{entity_type}
    B -->|Calendar Event| C[Regular events]
    B -->|Reminder| D[Tasks/Reminders]
```

## Key Data Flows

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[User creates reminder] --> B[CalendarItem created with reminder entity_type]
    B --> C[Set due_date and priority]
    B --> D[User adds alarm/alert]
    D --> E[Alarm record created]
    B --> F[User sets repeat pattern]
    F --> G[Recurrence record created]
    B --> H[User marks complete]
    H --> I[completion_date set]
```

## Key Fields for Reminders

- **summary**: The title of the reminder
- **description**: Details or notes about the reminder
- **due_date**: When the reminder is due
- **priority**: The priority level (high, medium, low)
- **completion_date**: When the reminder was marked as completed (null if not completed)
- **entity_type**: Identifies this as a reminder rather than a calendar event
- **calendar_id**: Which reminder list this belongs to (reminder lists are stored as Calendar records)

This shared database design allows Apple to efficiently integrate reminders with calendar functionality while maintaining separate views in the user interface.

Apple Notes and Reminders Database Documentation

Apple Notes and Reminders Databases Overview

Database Locations

graph TD A[macOS User Data] --> B[Notes Database] A --> C[Calendar/Reminders Database] B --> D[~/Library/Containers/com.apple.Notes/Data/Library/Notes/] B --> E[NotesV7.storedata and related files] C --> F[~/Library/Group Containers/group.com.apple.calendar/] C --> G[Calendar.sqlitedb]

Database Architecture Overview

flowchart LR subgraph "Apple Notes" N1[ZNOTE\nMetadata about notes] --- N2[ZNOTEBODY\nHTML content] N1 --- N3[ZATTACHMENT\nFiles & images] N4[ZFOLDER\nNote folders] --- N1 N5[ZACCOUNT\nSync accounts] --- N4 end subgraph "Apple Reminders/Calendar" R1[Calendar\nReminder lists] --- R2[CalendarItem\nReminders & events] R2 --- R3[Alarm\nReminder alerts] R2 --- R4[Recurrence\nRepeat patterns] R2 --- R5[Attachment\nFiles & links] end

Data Storage Model

Both databases use SQLite with a similar architecture:

graph TD A[Core Tables] --> B[Main data entities] A --> C[Relationship tables] A --> D[Support/metadata tables] E[Storage Files] --> F[Main .storedata/.sqlitedb file] E --> G[WAL files\nWrite-ahead logging] E --> H[SHM files\nShared memory]

How to Access the Data

flowchart TD A[Backup Files] --> B{Access Method} B --> C[Direct SQLite Queries] B --> D[Python with sqlite3] B --> E[Export Scripts] C --> F[Query core tables\nwith JOIN statements] D --> G[Object mapping\nto app entities] E --> H[Convert to JSON, XML,\nor Markdown]

Backup Approach

The included backup-data.sh script backs up these databases using the following approach:

sequenceDiagram participant User participant Script as backup-data.sh participant System as File System User->>Script: Execute script Script->>System: Create data directory Script->>System: Copy Notes database files Note over Script,System: NotesV7.storedata and related files Script->>System: Copy Calendar database file Note over Script,System: Calendar.sqlitedb Script->>User: Show confirmation

These databases contain all your notes and reminders data, allowing for backup, analysis, or export via custom tools.

Apple Notes Database Schema

The Apple Notes database uses a SQLite structure with several key tables that manage notes, their content, folders, and attachments.

Core Tables Relationship Diagram

erDiagram ZNOTE ||--o{ ZNOTEBODY : "has content" ZNOTE ||--o{ ZATTACHMENT : "has attachments" ZFOLDER ||--o{ ZNOTE : "contains" ZACCOUNT ||--o{ ZFOLDER : "has folders" ZNOTE { int Z_PK int ZBODY int ZFOLDER timestamp ZDATECREATED timestamp ZDATEEDITED string ZTITLE blob ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID } ZNOTEBODY { int Z_PK int ZNOTE string ZHTMLSTRING } ZFOLDER { int Z_PK int ZPARENT int ZACCOUNT string ZNAME } ZATTACHMENT { int Z_PK int ZNOTE string ZCONTENTID blob ZFILEURL } ZACCOUNT { int Z_PK string ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION string ZEMAILADDRESS }

Data Flow in Notes

graph TD A[User creates note] --> B[ZNOTE record created] B --> C[ZNOTEBODY record stores content] B --> D[ZFOLDER links to note] A --> E[User adds attachment] E --> F[ZATTACHMENT record created] F --> B

Key Relationships

  • ZNOTE to ZNOTEBODY: One-to-one relationship - each note has one body record that contains the HTML content
  • ZNOTE to ZFOLDER: Many-to-one relationship - many notes can be in a single folder
  • ZFOLDER to ZFOLDER: Self-referencing relationship through ZPARENT field - creates folder hierarchy
  • ZNOTE to ZATTACHMENT: One-to-many relationship - a note can have multiple attachments
  • ZACCOUNT to ZFOLDER: One-to-many relationship - an account can have multiple folders

This database design allows Apple Notes to efficiently store and organize notes with rich content across multiple devices and accounts.

Apple Reminders Database Schema

The Apple Reminders system stores its data within the Calendar database (Calendar.sqlitedb). This database handles both calendar events and reminders with a shared set of tables.

Core Tables Relationship Diagram

erDiagram Calendar ||--o{ CalendarItem : "contains" CalendarItem ||--o{ Alarm : "has alarms" CalendarItem ||--o{ Recurrence : "has recurrence" CalendarItem ||--o{ Participant : "has participants" CalendarItem ||--o{ Attachment : "has attachments" Calendar { int ROWID string title int color int type int external_id } CalendarItem { int ROWID string summary string description real start_date real end_date int calendar_id real due_date int priority real completion_date real creation_date int entity_type int hidden } Alarm { int ROWID int calendaritem_owner_id real fire_date int type } Recurrence { int ROWID int owner_id int frequency int interval int end_date_type } Attachment { int ROWID int owner_id string filename blob data } Participant { int ROWID int owner_id int type string name string email }

Distinguishing Reminders from Calendar Events

In the CalendarItem table, reminders and calendar events are differentiated by the entity_type field:

graph TD A[CalendarItem] --> B{entity_type} B -->|Calendar Event| C[Regular events] B -->|Reminder| D[Tasks/Reminders]

Key Data Flows

graph TD A[User creates reminder] --> B[CalendarItem created with reminder entity_type] B --> C[Set due_date and priority] B --> D[User adds alarm/alert] D --> E[Alarm record created] B --> F[User sets repeat pattern] F --> G[Recurrence record created] B --> H[User marks complete] H --> I[completion_date set]

Key Fields for Reminders

  • summary: The title of the reminder
  • description: Details or notes about the reminder
  • due_date: When the reminder is due
  • priority: The priority level (high, medium, low)
  • completion_date: When the reminder was marked as completed (null if not completed)
  • entity_type: Identifies this as a reminder rather than a calendar event
  • calendar_id: Which reminder list this belongs to (reminder lists are stored as Calendar records)

This shared database design allows Apple to efficiently integrate reminders with calendar functionality while maintaining separate views in the user interface.

file.content:
# Apple Notes Database Schema

The Apple Notes database uses a SQLite structure with several key tables that manage notes, their content, folders, and attachments.

## Core Tables Relationship Diagram

```mermaid
erDiagram
    ZNOTE ||--o{ ZNOTEBODY : "has content"
    ZNOTE ||--o{ ZATTACHMENT : "has attachments"
    ZFOLDER ||--o{ ZNOTE : "contains"
    ZACCOUNT ||--o{ ZFOLDER : "has folders"
    
    ZNOTE {
        int Z_PK
        int ZBODY
        int ZFOLDER
        timestamp ZDATECREATED
        timestamp ZDATEEDITED
        string ZTITLE
        blob ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID
    }
    
    ZNOTEBODY {
        int Z_PK
        int ZNOTE
        string ZHTMLSTRING
    }
    
    ZFOLDER {
        int Z_PK
        int ZPARENT
        int ZACCOUNT
        string ZNAME
    }
    
    ZATTACHMENT {
        int Z_PK
        int ZNOTE
        string ZCONTENTID
        blob ZFILEURL
    }
    
    ZACCOUNT {
        int Z_PK
        string ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION
        string ZEMAILADDRESS
    }
```

## Data Flow in Notes

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[User creates note] --> B[ZNOTE record created]
    B --> C[ZNOTEBODY record stores content]
    B --> D[ZFOLDER links to note]
    A --> E[User adds attachment]
    E --> F[ZATTACHMENT record created]
    F --> B
```

## Key Relationships

- **ZNOTE to ZNOTEBODY**: One-to-one relationship - each note has one body record that contains the HTML content
- **ZNOTE to ZFOLDER**: Many-to-one relationship - many notes can be in a single folder
- **ZFOLDER to ZFOLDER**: Self-referencing relationship through ZPARENT field - creates folder hierarchy
- **ZNOTE to ZATTACHMENT**: One-to-many relationship - a note can have multiple attachments
- **ZACCOUNT to ZFOLDER**: One-to-many relationship - an account can have multiple folders

This database design allows Apple Notes to efficiently store and organize notes with rich content across multiple devices and accounts.

file.content:
# Apple Reminders Database Schema

The Apple Reminders system stores its data within the Calendar database (Calendar.sqlitedb). This database handles both calendar events and reminders with a shared set of tables.

## Core Tables Relationship Diagram

```mermaid
erDiagram
    Calendar ||--o{ CalendarItem : "contains"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Alarm : "has alarms"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Recurrence : "has recurrence"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Participant : "has participants"
    CalendarItem ||--o{ Attachment : "has attachments"
    
    Calendar {
        int ROWID
        string title
        int color
        int type
        int external_id
    }
    
    CalendarItem {
        int ROWID
        string summary
        string description
        real start_date
        real end_date
        int calendar_id
        real due_date
        int priority
        real completion_date
        real creation_date
        int entity_type
        int hidden
    }
    
    Alarm {
        int ROWID
        int calendaritem_owner_id
        real fire_date
        int type
    }
    
    Recurrence {
        int ROWID
        int owner_id
        int frequency
        int interval
        int end_date_type
    }
    
    Attachment {
        int ROWID
        int owner_id
        string filename
        blob data
    }
    
    Participant {
        int ROWID
        int owner_id
        int type
        string name
        string email
    }
```

## Distinguishing Reminders from Calendar Events

In the CalendarItem table, reminders and calendar events are differentiated by the `entity_type` field:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[CalendarItem] --> B{entity_type}
    B -->|Calendar Event| C[Regular events]
    B -->|Reminder| D[Tasks/Reminders]
```

## Key Data Flows

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[User creates reminder] --> B[CalendarItem created with reminder entity_type]
    B --> C[Set due_date and priority]
    B --> D[User adds alarm/alert]
    D --> E[Alarm record created]
    B --> F[User sets repeat pattern]
    F --> G[Recurrence record created]
    B --> H[User marks complete]
    H --> I[completion_date set]
```

## Key Fields for Reminders

- **summary**: The title of the reminder
- **description**: Details or notes about the reminder
- **due_date**: When the reminder is due
- **priority**: The priority level (high, medium, low)
- **completion_date**: When the reminder was marked as completed (null if not completed)
- **entity_type**: Identifies this as a reminder rather than a calendar event
- **calendar_id**: Which reminder list this belongs to (reminder lists are stored as Calendar records)

This shared database design allows Apple to efficiently integrate reminders with calendar functionality while maintaining separate views in the user interface.

file.content:
# Apple Notes and Reminders Databases Overview

## Database Locations

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[macOS User Data] --> B[Notes Database]
    A --> C[Calendar/Reminders Database]
    
    B --> D[~/Library/Containers/com.apple.Notes/Data/Library/Notes/]
    B --> E[NotesV7.storedata and related files]
    
    C --> F[~/Library/Group Containers/group.com.apple.calendar/]
    C --> G[Calendar.sqlitedb]
```

## Database Architecture Overview

```mermaid
flowchart LR
    subgraph "Apple Notes"
        N1[ZNOTE\nMetadata about notes] --- N2[ZNOTEBODY\nHTML content]
        N1 --- N3[ZATTACHMENT\nFiles & images]
        N4[ZFOLDER\nNote folders] --- N1
        N5[ZACCOUNT\nSync accounts] --- N4
    end
    
    subgraph "Apple Reminders/Calendar"
        R1[Calendar\nReminder lists] --- R2[CalendarItem\nReminders & events]
        R2 --- R3[Alarm\nReminder alerts]
        R2 --- R4[Recurrence\nRepeat patterns]
        R2 --- R5[Attachment\nFiles & links]
    end
```

## Data Storage Model

Both databases use SQLite with a similar architecture:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Core Tables] --> B[Main data entities]
    A --> C[Relationship tables]
    A --> D[Support/metadata tables]
    
    E[Storage Files] --> F[Main .storedata/.sqlitedb file]
    E --> G[WAL files\nWrite-ahead logging]
    E --> H[SHM files\nShared memory]
```

## How to Access the Data

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Backup Files] --> B{Access Method}
    
    B --> C[Direct SQLite Queries]
    B --> D[Python with sqlite3]
    B --> E[Export Scripts]
    
    C --> F[Query core tables\nwith JOIN statements]
    D --> G[Object mapping\nto app entities]
    E --> H[Convert to JSON, XML,\nor Markdown]
```

## Backup Approach

The included `backup-data.sh` script backs up these databases using the following approach:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Script as backup-data.sh
    participant System as File System
    
    User->>Script: Execute script
    Script->>System: Create data directory
    Script->>System: Copy Notes database files
    Note over Script,System: NotesV7.storedata and related files
    Script->>System: Copy Calendar database file
    Note over Script,System: Calendar.sqlitedb
    Script->>User: Show confirmation
```

These databases contain all your notes and reminders data, allowing for backup, analysis, or export via custom tools.

Apple Notes and Reminders Database Documentation

Apple Notes and Reminders Databases Overview

Database Locations

  • macOS User Data
    • Notes Database
      • ~/Library/Containers/com.apple.Notes/Data/Library/Notes/
      • NotesV7.storedata and related files
    • Calendar/Reminders Database
      • ~/Library/Group Containers/group.com.apple.calendar/
      • Calendar.sqlitedb

Database Architecture Overview

  • Apple Notes
    • ZNOTE (Metadata about notes)
      • Connected to ZNOTEBODY (HTML content)
      • Connected to ZATTACHMENT (Files & images)
    • ZFOLDER (Note folders)
      • Connected to ZNOTE
    • ZACCOUNT (Sync accounts)
      • Connected to ZFOLDER
  • Apple Reminders/Calendar
    • Calendar (Reminder lists)
      • Connected to CalendarItem (Reminders & events)
    • CalendarItem
      • Connected to Alarm (Reminder alerts)
      • Connected to Recurrence (Repeat patterns)
      • Connected to Attachment (Files & links)

Data Storage Model

Both databases use SQLite with a similar architecture:

  • Core Tables
    • Main data entities
    • Relationship tables
    • Support/metadata tables
  • Storage Files
    • Main .storedata/.sqlitedb file
    • WAL files (Write-ahead logging)
    • SHM files (Shared memory)

How to Access the Data

  • Backup Files
    • Access Methods:
      • Direct SQLite Queries
        • Query core tables with JOIN statements
      • Python with sqlite3
        • Object mapping to app entities
      • Export Scripts
        • Convert to JSON, XML, or Markdown

Backup Approach

The included backup-data.sh script backs up these databases using the following approach:

  • User executes script
  • Script creates data directory
  • Script copies Notes database files (NotesV7.storedata and related files)
  • Script copies Calendar database file (Calendar.sqlitedb)
  • Script shows confirmation to user

These databases contain all your notes and reminders data, allowing for backup, analysis, or export via custom tools.

Apple Notes Database Schema

The Apple Notes database uses a SQLite structure with several key tables that manage notes, their content, folders, and attachments.

Core Tables

  • ZNOTE
    • int Z_PK
    • int ZBODY
    • int ZFOLDER
    • timestamp ZDATECREATED
    • timestamp ZDATEEDITED
    • string ZTITLE
    • blob ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID
  • ZNOTEBODY
    • int Z_PK
    • int ZNOTE
    • string ZHTMLSTRING
  • ZFOLDER
    • int Z_PK
    • int ZPARENT
    • int ZACCOUNT
    • string ZNAME
  • ZATTACHMENT
    • int Z_PK
    • int ZNOTE
    • string ZCONTENTID
    • blob ZFILEURL
  • ZACCOUNT
    • int Z_PK
    • string ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION
    • string ZEMAILADDRESS

Data Flow in Notes

  • User creates note
    • ZNOTE record created
      • ZNOTEBODY record stores content
      • ZFOLDER links to note
    • User adds attachment
      • ZATTACHMENT record created (linked to ZNOTE)

Key Relationships

  • ZNOTE to ZNOTEBODY: One-to-one relationship - each note has one body record that contains the HTML content
  • ZNOTE to ZFOLDER: Many-to-one relationship - many notes can be in a single folder
  • ZFOLDER to ZFOLDER: Self-referencing relationship through ZPARENT field - creates folder hierarchy
  • ZNOTE to ZATTACHMENT: One-to-many relationship - a note can have multiple attachments
  • ZACCOUNT to ZFOLDER: One-to-many relationship - an account can have multiple folders

This database design allows Apple Notes to efficiently store and organize notes with rich content across multiple devices and accounts.

Apple Reminders Database Schema

The Apple Reminders system stores its data within the Calendar database (Calendar.sqlitedb). This database handles both calendar events and reminders with a shared set of tables.

Core Tables

  • Calendar
    • int ROWID
    • string title
    • int color
    • int type
    • int external_id
  • CalendarItem
    • int ROWID
    • string summary
    • string description
    • real start_date
    • real end_date
    • int calendar_id
    • real due_date
    • int priority
    • real completion_date
    • real creation_date
    • int entity_type
    • int hidden
  • Alarm
    • int ROWID
    • int calendaritem_owner_id
    • real fire_date
    • int type
  • Recurrence
    • int ROWID
    • int owner_id
    • int frequency
    • int interval
    • int end_date_type
  • Attachment
    • int ROWID
    • int owner_id
    • string filename
    • blob data
  • Participant
    • int ROWID
    • int owner_id
    • int type
    • string name
    • string email

Distinguishing Reminders from Calendar Events

In the CalendarItem table, reminders and calendar events are differentiated by the entity_type field:

  • CalendarItem
    • entity_type
      • Calendar Event Regular events
      • Reminder Tasks/Reminders

Key Data Flows

  • User creates reminder
    • CalendarItem created with reminder entity_type
      • Set due_date and priority
      • User adds alarm/alert Alarm record created
      • User sets repeat pattern Recurrence record created
      • User marks complete completion_date set

Key Fields for Reminders

  • summary: The title of the reminder
  • description: Details or notes about the reminder
  • due_date: When the reminder is due
  • priority: The priority level (high, medium, low)
  • completion_date: When the reminder was marked as completed (null if not completed)
  • entity_type: Identifies this as a reminder rather than a calendar event
  • calendar_id: Which reminder list this belongs to (reminder lists are stored as Calendar records)

This shared database design allows Apple to efficiently integrate reminders with calendar functionality while maintaining separate views in the user interface.

    • real completion_date
    • real creation_date
    • int entity_type
    • int hidden
  • Alarm
    • int ROWID
    • int calendaritem_owner_id
    • real fire_date
    • int type
  • Recurrence
    • int ROWID
    • int owner_id
    • int frequency
    • int interval
    • int end_date_type
  • Attachment
    • int ROWID
    • int owner_id
    • string filename
    • blob data
  • Participant
    • int ROWID
    • int owner_id
    • int type
    • string name
    • string email

Distinguishing Reminders from Calendar Events

In the CalendarItem table, reminders and calendar events are differentiated by the entity_type field:

  • CalendarItem
    • entity_type
      • Calendar Event Regular events
      • Reminder Tasks/Reminders

Key Data Flows

  • User creates reminder
    • CalendarItem created with reminder entity_type
      • Set due_date and priority
      • User adds alarm/alert Alarm record created
      • User sets repeat pattern Recurrence record created
      • User marks complete completion_date set

Key Fields for Reminders

  • summary: The title of the reminder
  • description: Details or notes about the reminder
  • due_date: When the reminder is due
  • priority: The priority level (high, medium, low)
  • completion_date: When the reminder was marked as completed (null if not completed)
  • entity_type: Identifies this as a reminder rather than a calendar event
  • calendar_id: Which reminder list this belongs to (reminder lists are stored as Calendar records)

This shared database design allows Apple to efficiently integrate reminders with calendar functionality while maintaining separate views in the user interface.

Apple Notes and Reminders Database Structure

Apple Notes Database

A simple representation of the Notes database structure and relationships:

Core Entities and Relationships

  • ZACCOUNT (Account information)
    • Has many ZFOLDER (Folders)
    • Fields: Z_PK, ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION, ZEMAILADDRESS
  • ZFOLDER (Note folders)
    • Has many ZNOTE (Notes)
    • Can have parent ZFOLDER (Nested folders)
    • Belongs to one ZACCOUNT
    • Fields: Z_PK, ZPARENT, ZACCOUNT, ZNAME
  • ZNOTE (Note metadata)
    • Has one ZNOTEBODY (Content)
    • Has many ZATTACHMENT (Files, images)
    • Belongs to one ZFOLDER
    • Fields: Z_PK, ZBODY, ZFOLDER, ZDATECREATED, ZDATEEDITED, ZTITLE, ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID
  • ZNOTEBODY (Note content)
    • Belongs to one ZNOTE
    • Fields: Z_PK, ZNOTE, ZHTMLSTRING
  • ZATTACHMENT (Files and media)
    • Belongs to one ZNOTE
    • Fields: Z_PK, ZNOTE, ZCONTENTID, ZFILEURL

Note: The arrows ( and ) indicate the direction of the relationship. For example, ZACCOUNT ZFOLDER means one account can have many folders, while ZNOTE ZFOLDER means many notes belong to one folder.

Apple Reminders Database

A simple representation of the Reminders database structure and relationships (stored in Calendar.sqlitedb):

Core Entities and Relationships

  • Calendar (Reminder lists)
    • Has many CalendarItem (Reminders or events)
    • Fields: ROWID, title, color, type, external_id
  • CalendarItem (Reminder or calendar event)
    • Has many Alarm (Alerts)
    • Has many Recurrence (Repeat patterns)
    • Has many Attachment (Files)
    • Has many Participant (People)
    • Belongs to one Calendar
    • Key fields: ROWID, summary, description, due_date, priority, completion_date, entity_type, calendar_id
  • Alarm (Reminder alerts)
    • Belongs to one CalendarItem
    • Fields: ROWID, calendaritem_owner_id, fire_date, type
  • Recurrence (Repeating patterns)
    • Belongs to one CalendarItem
    • Fields: ROWID, owner_id, frequency, interval, end_date_type
  • Attachment (Files and links)
    • Belongs to one CalendarItem
    • Fields: ROWID, owner_id, filename, data
  • Participant (People associated with reminders)
    • Belongs to one CalendarItem
    • Fields: ROWID, owner_id, type, name, email

Note: In the CalendarItem table, reminders and calendar events are differentiated by the entity_type field. Reminders have one value, calendar events have another.

input.content:
Apple Notes and Reminders Database Structure

Apple Notes Database

A human-readable representation of the Notes database structure:

Core Entities and Relationships

  • Account - Syncing account information like iCloud or Gmail (ZACCOUNT)
    • Contains multiple folders
    • Key data: Account name, email address, unique ID
  • Folder - Container for organizing notes (ZFOLDER)
    • Contains multiple notes
    • Can have subfolders (nested folders)
    • Belongs to one account
    • Key data: Folder name, parent folder ID, account ID
  • Note - Main note record with metadata (ZNOTE)
    • Has one body (content)
    • Can have multiple attachments
    • Belongs to one folder
    • Key data: Title, creation date, modification date, unique ID
  • Note Content - The actual text and formatting of a note (ZNOTEBODY)
    • Belongs to one note
    • Key data: HTML-formatted text content
  • Attachment - Files, images, and other media in notes (ZATTACHMENT)
    • Belongs to one note
    • Key data: File reference, content ID, file type

Note: The arrows ( and ) show relationship direction. For example, an Account Folder means one account can have many folders, while Note Folder means many notes belong to one folder.

Apple Reminders Database

A human-readable representation of the Reminders database structure (stored in the Calendar database):

Core Entities and Relationships

  • Reminder List - Collection of reminders (like "Personal" or "Work") (Calendar)
    • Contains multiple reminders
    • Key data: List name, color, type identifier
  • Reminder - Individual task or to-do item (CalendarItem with reminder entity_type)
    • Can have alerts (alarms)
    • Can have repeat patterns (recurrence)
    • Can have files attached
    • Can have people assigned
    • Belongs to one reminder list
    • Key data: Title, notes, due date, priority, completion status
  • Alert - Notification for a reminder (Alarm)
    • Belongs to one reminder
    • Key data: Alert time, notification type
  • Repeat Pattern - How a reminder repeats (daily, weekly, etc.) (Recurrence)
    • Belongs to one reminder
    • Key data: Frequency type, interval, end condition
  • Attachment - Files or links connected to a reminder (Attachment)
    • Belongs to one reminder
    • Key data: Filename, file data or URL
  • Person - Someone assigned to or sharing a reminder (Participant)
    • Associated with one reminder
    • Key data: Name, email, role type

Note: The Calendar database handles both reminders and calendar events. They share the same tables but are distinguished by the "entity_type" field in the CalendarItem table.

input.content:
# Database Field Mappings

This document maps fields from Apple's Notes and Reminders databases to our new SQLite database schema.

## Notes Database Mappings

### Notes Table

```sql
-- Main notes table that stores core note data
CREATE TABLE notes (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the note
  -- ZNOTE.Z_PK  id
  
  -- Title of the note
  -- ZNOTE.ZTITLE  title
  title TEXT,
  
  -- Note creation timestamp
  -- ZNOTE.ZDATECREATED  created_at
  created_at TIMESTAMP,
  
  -- Note last modified timestamp
  -- ZNOTE.ZDATEEDITED  updated_at
  updated_at TIMESTAMP,
  
  -- Full content of the note
  -- ZNOTEBODY.ZHTMLSTRING  content
  content TEXT,
  
  -- Folder ID this note belongs to
  -- ZNOTE.ZFOLDER  folder_id
  folder_id INTEGER,
  
  -- Universal unique identifier from Apple Notes
  -- ZNOTE.ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID  original_id
  original_id TEXT,
  
  -- Flag indicating if note is starred/important
  -- No direct mapping, but could be derived from Apple's data
  is_starred BOOLEAN DEFAULT 0,
  
  -- Additional metadata as JSON
  -- Could store other ZNOTE fields we might need later
  metadata TEXT
);
```

### Folders Table

```sql
-- Folders to organize notes
CREATE TABLE folders (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the folder
  -- ZFOLDER.Z_PK  id
  
  -- Name of the folder
  -- ZFOLDER.ZNAME  name
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  
  -- Parent folder ID for nested folders
  -- ZFOLDER.ZPARENT  parent_id
  parent_id INTEGER,
  
  -- Account this folder belongs to
  -- ZFOLDER.ZACCOUNT  account_id
  account_id INTEGER,
  
  -- Path from root folder (for easier querying)
  -- Computed from folder hierarchy
  path TEXT
);
```

### Accounts Table

```sql
-- User accounts (iCloud, Gmail, etc.)
CREATE TABLE accounts (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the account
  -- ZACCOUNT.Z_PK  id
  
  -- Account name/description
  -- ZACCOUNT.ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION  name
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  
  -- Email address associated with account
  -- ZACCOUNT.ZEMAILADDRESS  email
  email TEXT,
  
  -- Account type (iCloud, Google, etc.)
  -- Derived from ZACCOUNT data
  type TEXT
);
```

### Attachments Table

```sql
-- Files and media attached to notes
CREATE TABLE attachments (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the attachment
  -- ZATTACHMENT.Z_PK  id
  
  -- Note this attachment belongs to
  -- ZATTACHMENT.ZNOTE  note_id
  note_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  
  -- Original content ID from Apple Notes
  -- ZATTACHMENT.ZCONTENTID  content_id
  content_id TEXT,
  
  -- Type of attachment (image, pdf, etc.)
  -- Derived from file data
  type TEXT,
  
  -- Filename of the attachment
  -- Extracted from ZATTACHMENT.ZFILEURL
  filename TEXT,
  
  -- Local file path where attachment is stored
  -- Our own storage system referencing the extracted file
  file_path TEXT,
  
  -- Thumbnail for image attachments
  -- Generated from original attachment
  thumbnail BLOB,
  
  -- File size in bytes
  -- Computed from the file
  size INTEGER,
  
  -- MIME type of the file
  -- Determined from file data
  mime_type TEXT
);
```

## Reminders Database Mappings

### Reminder Lists Table

```sql
-- Lists that contain reminders (equivalent to Calendar for reminders)
CREATE TABLE reminder_lists (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the reminder list
  -- Calendar.ROWID  id
  
  -- Name of the reminder list
  -- Calendar.title  name
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  
  -- Color of the list (in hex format)
  -- Calendar.color  color_hex
  color_hex TEXT,
  
  -- Apple's original external ID
  -- Calendar.external_id  external_id
  external_id TEXT,
  
  -- List order/position
  -- No direct mapping, assigned during import
  position INTEGER
);
```

### Reminders Table

```sql
-- Individual reminders/tasks
CREATE TABLE reminders (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the reminder
  -- CalendarItem.ROWID  id
  
  -- Title of the reminder
  -- CalendarItem.summary  title
  title TEXT NOT NULL,
  
  -- Detailed notes about the reminder
  -- CalendarItem.description  notes
  notes TEXT,
  
  -- When the reminder is due
  -- CalendarItem.due_date  due_date
  due_date TIMESTAMP,
  
  -- Priority level (1=high, 5=medium, 9=low)
  -- CalendarItem.priority  priority
  priority INTEGER,
  
  -- Whether the reminder is completed
  -- (CalendarItem.completion_date IS NOT NULL)  is_completed
  is_completed BOOLEAN DEFAULT 0,
  
  -- When the reminder was marked complete
  -- CalendarItem.completion_date  completed_at
  completed_at TIMESTAMP,
  
  -- When the reminder was created
  -- CalendarItem.creation_date  created_at
  created_at TIMESTAMP,
  
  -- The list this reminder belongs to
  -- CalendarItem.calendar_id  list_id
  list_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  
  -- Start date (if applicable)
  -- CalendarItem.start_date  start_date
  start_date TIMESTAMP,
  
  -- Flag if reminder is hidden
  -- CalendarItem.hidden  is_hidden
  is_hidden BOOLEAN DEFAULT 0
);
```

### Reminder Alerts Table

```sql
-- Notifications for reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_alerts (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the alert
  -- Alarm.ROWID  id
  
  -- Reminder this alert belongs to
  -- Alarm.calendaritem_owner_id  reminder_id
  reminder_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  
  -- When the alert should trigger
  -- Alarm.fire_date  alert_time
  alert_time TIMESTAMP NOT NULL,
  
  -- Type of alert (notification, email, etc.)
  -- Alarm.type  alert_type
  alert_type INTEGER
);
```

### Reminder Recurrences Table

```sql
-- Repeat patterns for reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_recurrences (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the recurrence
  -- Recurrence.ROWID  id
  
  -- Reminder this recurrence belongs to
  -- Recurrence.owner_id  reminder_id
  reminder_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  
  -- Frequency type (daily, weekly, monthly, yearly)
  -- Recurrence.frequency  frequency
  frequency TEXT NOT NULL,
  
  -- Interval between occurrences
  -- Recurrence.interval  interval
  interval INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 1,
  
  -- How the recurrence ends (never, on date, after count)
  -- Recurrence.end_date_type  end_type
  end_type TEXT,
  
  -- End date if applicable
  -- Derived from Recurrence data
  end_date TIMESTAMP,
  
  -- End after this many occurrences
  -- Derived from Recurrence data
  end_count INTEGER
);
```

### Reminder Attachments Table

```sql
-- Files attached to reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_attachments (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the attachment
  -- Attachment.ROWID  id
  
  -- Reminder this attachment belongs to
  -- Attachment.owner_id  reminder_id
  reminder_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  
  -- Filename of the attachment
  -- Attachment.filename  filename
  filename TEXT,
  
  -- Binary data or reference to file
  -- Either Attachment.data or our own file reference
  file_data BLOB,
  
  -- Local file path where attachment is stored
  -- Our own storage system referencing the extracted file
  file_path TEXT
);
```

### Reminder Participants Table

```sql
-- People assigned to or tagged in reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_participants (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  -- Unique identifier for the participant
  -- Participant.ROWID  id
  
  -- Reminder this participant is associated with
  -- Participant.owner_id  reminder_id
  reminder_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  
  -- Name of the person
  -- Participant.name  name
  name TEXT,
  
  -- Email address of the person
  -- Participant.email  email
  email TEXT,
  
  -- Role of participant (assigned, FYI, etc.)
  -- Participant.type  role
  role TEXT
);
```

## Additional Tables

```sql
-- For tracking tags/categories
CREATE TABLE tags (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL
);

-- For linking tags to notes
CREATE TABLE note_tags (
  note_id INTEGER,
  tag_id INTEGER,
  PRIMARY KEY (note_id, tag_id)
);

-- For linking tags to reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_tags (
  reminder_id INTEGER,
  tag_id INTEGER,
  PRIMARY KEY (reminder_id, tag_id)
);

-- For tracking synchronization status
CREATE TABLE sync_info (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  last_sync TIMESTAMP,
  source_type TEXT,
  source_id TEXT,
  status TEXT
);
```

-- Apple Notes and Reminders export schema

-- User accounts (iCloud, Gmail, etc.)
CREATE TABLE accounts (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  email TEXT,
  type TEXT
);

-- Folders to organize notes
CREATE TABLE folders (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  parent_id INTEGER,
  account_id INTEGER,
  path TEXT,
  FOREIGN KEY (parent_id) REFERENCES folders(id),
  FOREIGN KEY (account_id) REFERENCES accounts(id)
);

-- Main notes table that stores core note data
CREATE TABLE notes (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  title TEXT,
  created_at TIMESTAMP,
  updated_at TIMESTAMP,
  content TEXT,
  folder_id INTEGER,
  original_id TEXT,
  is_starred BOOLEAN DEFAULT 0,
  metadata TEXT,
  FOREIGN KEY (folder_id) REFERENCES folders(id)
);

-- Files and media attached to notes
CREATE TABLE attachments (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  note_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  content_id TEXT,
  type TEXT,
  filename TEXT,
  file_path TEXT,
  thumbnail BLOB,
  size INTEGER,
  mime_type TEXT,
  FOREIGN KEY (note_id) REFERENCES notes(id)
);

-- Lists that contain reminders (equivalent to Calendar for reminders)
CREATE TABLE lists (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  color_hex TEXT,
  external_id TEXT,
  position INTEGER
);

-- Individual reminders/tasks
CREATE TABLE reminders (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  title TEXT NOT NULL,
  notes TEXT,
  due_date TIMESTAMP,
  priority INTEGER,
  is_completed BOOLEAN DEFAULT 0,
  completed_at TIMESTAMP,
  created_at TIMESTAMP,
  list_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  start_date TIMESTAMP,
  is_hidden BOOLEAN DEFAULT 0,
  FOREIGN KEY (list_id) REFERENCES lists(id)
);

-- Notifications for reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_alerts (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  reminder_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  alert_time TIMESTAMP NOT NULL,
  alert_type INTEGER,
  FOREIGN KEY (reminder_id) REFERENCES reminders(id)
);

-- Repeat patterns for reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_recurrences (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  reminder_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  frequency TEXT NOT NULL,
  interval INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 1,
  end_type TEXT,
  end_date TIMESTAMP,
  end_count INTEGER,
  FOREIGN KEY (reminder_id) REFERENCES reminders(id)
);

-- Files attached to reminders
CREATE TABLE reminder_attachments (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  reminder_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  filename TEXT,
  file_data BLOB,
  file_path TEXT,
  FOREIGN KEY (reminder_id) REFERENCES reminders(id)
);

-- People assigned to or tagged in reminders

  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,

  email TEXT,
  role TEXT,
  FOREIGN KEY (reminder_id) REFERENCES reminders(id)
);

-- For tracking tags/categories
CREATE TABLE tags (

  name TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL
);

-- For linking tags to notes

);

-- For linking tags to reminders

#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Import data from Apple Notes and Reminders databases into our custom SQLite database.
"""

import sqlite3
import json
import os
import time
from datetime import datetime
import uuid

# Paths to databases
NOTES_DB_PATH = "data/NotesV7.storedata"
REMINDERS_DB_PATH = "data/Calendar.sqlitedb"
TARGET_DB_PATH = "apple.db"

# Apple epoch is seconds since Jan 1, 2001
APPLE_EPOCH = 978307200

def apple_time_to_timestamp(apple_time):
    """Convert Apple's time format to a standard timestamp"""
    if apple_time is None:
        return None
    try:
        # Apple time is seconds since Jan 1, 2001
        timestamp = APPLE_EPOCH + float(apple_time)
        return datetime.fromtimestamp(timestamp).isoformat()
    except (ValueError, TypeError):
        return None

def get_file_extension(mime_type):
    """Get file extension based on MIME type"""
    mime_map = {
        'image/jpeg': 'jpg',
        'image/png': 'png',
        'image/gif': 'gif',
        'application/pdf': 'pdf',
        'text/plain': 'txt',
        'text/html': 'html',
    }
    return mime_map.get(mime_type, 'bin')

def extract_filename(file_url):
    """Extract filename from file URL or generate one if not possible"""
    if not file_url:
        return f"attachment_{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}"
    
    try:
        # Try to extract the filename from the URL
        # This is a simplistic approach and might need to be refined
        parts = file_url.split('/')
        filename = parts[-1]
        if not filename:
            return f"attachment_{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}"
        return filename
    except:
        return f"attachment_{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}"

def import_accounts(notes_conn, target_conn):
    """Import accounts from Apple Notes to our database"""
    print("Importing accounts...")
    
    # Get accounts from Notes database
    cursor = notes_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("SELECT Z_PK, ZACCOUNTDESCRIPTION, ZEMAILADDRESS FROM ZACCOUNT")
    accounts = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for account in accounts:
        pk, description, email = account
        
        # Determine account type based on email domain
        account_type = "iCloud"
        if email and "@gmail" in email.lower():
            account_type = "Google"
        elif email and "@outlook" in email.lower() or "@hotmail" in email.lower():
            account_type = "Microsoft"
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO accounts (id, name, email, type) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (pk, description or "Unknown Account", email, account_type)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(accounts)} accounts")

def import_folders(notes_conn, target_conn):
    """Import folders from Apple Notes to our database"""
    print("Importing folders...")
    
    # Get folders from Notes database
    cursor = notes_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("SELECT Z_PK, ZNAME, ZPARENT, ZACCOUNT FROM ZFOLDER")
    folders = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for folder in folders:
        pk, name, parent_id, account_id = folder
        
        # For now, we'll set the path as just the name
        # In a real implementation, we'd compute the full path
        path = name or "Unknown Folder"
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO folders (id, name, parent_id, account_id, path) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (pk, name or "Unknown Folder", parent_id, account_id, path)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(folders)} folders")

def import_notes(notes_conn, target_conn):
    """Import notes from Apple Notes to our database"""
    print("Importing notes...")
    
    # Get notes from Notes database
    cursor = notes_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT n.Z_PK, n.ZTITLE, n.ZDATECREATED, n.ZDATEEDITED, 
               b.ZHTMLSTRING, n.ZFOLDER, n.ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID
        FROM ZNOTE n
        LEFT JOIN ZNOTEBODY b ON n.ZBODY = b.Z_PK
    """)
    notes = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for note in notes:
        pk, title, created, edited, content, folder_id, uuid = note
        
        # Convert Apple timestamps to ISO format
        created_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(created)
        updated_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(edited)
        
        # Create metadata JSON for any extra fields we might want to keep
        metadata = json.dumps({"apple_uuid": uuid})
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            """INSERT INTO notes 
               (id, title, created_at, updated_at, content, folder_id, original_id, metadata) 
               VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)""",
            (pk, title or "Untitled Note", created_at, updated_at, 
             content, folder_id, uuid, metadata)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(notes)} notes")

def import_attachments(notes_conn, target_conn):
    """Import attachments from Apple Notes to our database"""
    print("Importing note attachments...")
    
    # Get attachments from Notes database
    cursor = notes_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("SELECT Z_PK, ZNOTE, ZCONTENTID, ZFILEURL FROM ZATTACHMENT")
    attachments = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for attachment in attachments:
        pk, note_id, content_id, file_url = attachment
        
        # Determine filename and type
        filename = extract_filename(file_url)
        file_type = "unknown"
        if filename:
            ext = filename.split('.')[-1].lower() if '.' in filename else ''
            if ext in ['jpg', 'jpeg', 'png', 'gif']:
                file_type = "image"
            elif ext == 'pdf':
                file_type = "pdf"
            elif ext in ['txt', 'md', 'rtf']:
                file_type = "text"
            elif ext in ['mov', 'mp4']:
                file_type = "video"
        
        # For now, we'll just reference the original attachments
        # In a real implementation, we'd extract and save them
        file_path = f"attachments/{content_id}" if content_id else None
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            """INSERT INTO attachments 
               (id, note_id, content_id, type, filename, file_path) 
               VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)""",
            (pk, note_id, content_id, file_type, filename, file_path)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(attachments)} note attachments")

def import_reminder_lists(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder lists from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder lists...")
    
    # Get reminder lists from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, title, color, external_id 
        FROM Calendar 
        WHERE Calendar.type = 0
    """)
    lists = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for i, lst in enumerate(lists):
        rowid, title, color, external_id = lst
        
        # Convert color to hex format if needed
        color_hex = f"#{color:06x}" if color else None
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO lists (id, name, color_hex, external_id, position) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, title or "Untitled List", color_hex, external_id, i)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(lists)} reminder lists")

def import_reminders(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminders from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminders...")
    
    # Get reminders from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, summary, description, start_date, end_date, due_date,
               priority, completion_date, creation_date, calendar_id, hidden
        FROM CalendarItem
        WHERE entity_type = 1
    """)
    reminders = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for reminder in reminders:
        (rowid, summary, description, start_date, end_date, due_date,
         priority, completion_date, creation_date, calendar_id, hidden) = reminder
        
        # Convert Apple timestamps to ISO format
        due_date_str = apple_time_to_timestamp(due_date)
        completed_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(completion_date)
        created_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(creation_date)
        start_date_str = apple_time_to_timestamp(start_date)
        
        # Set is_completed based on completion_date
        is_completed = 1 if completion_date else 0
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            """INSERT INTO reminders 
               (id, title, notes, due_date, priority, is_completed, completed_at, 
                created_at, list_id, start_date, is_hidden) 
               VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)""",
            (rowid, summary or "Untitled Reminder", description, due_date_str, 
             priority, is_completed, completed_at, created_at, 
             calendar_id, start_date_str, hidden or 0)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(reminders)} reminders")

def import_reminder_alerts(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder alerts from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder alerts...")
    
    # Get reminder alerts from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, calendaritem_owner_id, fire_date, type
        FROM Alarm
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Alarm.calendaritem_owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    alerts = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for alert in alerts:
        rowid, reminder_id, fire_date, alert_type = alert
        
        # Convert Apple timestamp
        alert_time = apple_time_to_timestamp(fire_date)
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO reminder_alerts (id, reminder_id, alert_time, alert_type) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, reminder_id, alert_time, alert_type)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(alerts)} reminder alerts")

def import_reminder_recurrences(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder recurrences from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder recurrences...")
    
    # Get reminder recurrences from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, owner_id, frequency, interval, end_date_type
        FROM Recurrence
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Recurrence.owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    recurrences = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for recurrence in recurrences:
        rowid, reminder_id, frequency, interval, end_date_type = recurrence
        
        # Map frequency value to text
        freq_map = {
            0: "daily",
            1: "weekly",
            2: "monthly",
            3: "yearly"
        }
        frequency_text = freq_map.get(frequency, "unknown")
        
        # Map end_date_type to text
        end_type_map = {
            0: "never",
            1: "on_date",
            2: "after_count"
        }
        end_type = end_type_map.get(end_date_type, "never")
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            """INSERT INTO reminder_recurrences 
               (id, reminder_id, frequency, interval, end_type) 
               VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)""",
            (rowid, reminder_id, frequency_text, interval or 1, end_type)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(recurrences)} reminder recurrences")

def import_reminder_attachments(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder attachments from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder attachments...")
    
    # Get reminder attachments from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, owner_id, filename
        FROM Attachment
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Attachment.owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    attachments = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for attachment in attachments:
        rowid, reminder_id, filename = attachment
        
        # For now, we'll just reference the filename
        # In a real implementation, we'd extract and save the binary data
        file_path = f"reminder_attachments/{rowid}_{filename}" if filename else None
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO reminder_attachments (id, reminder_id, filename, file_path) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, reminder_id, filename, file_path)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(attachments)} reminder attachments")

def import_reminder_participants(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder participants from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder participants...")
    
    # Get reminder participants from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, owner_id, type, name, email
        FROM Participant
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Participant.owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    participants = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for participant in participants:
        rowid, reminder_id, type_id, name, email = participant
        
        # Map participant type to role
        role_map = {
            0: "organizer",
            1: "required",
            2: "optional",
            3: "fyi"
        }
        role = role_map.get(type_id, "unknown")
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO reminder_participants (id, reminder_id, name, email, role) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, reminder_id, name, email, role)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(participants)} reminder participants")

def update_sync_info(target_conn):
    """Add sync info record"""
    print("Adding sync information...")
    
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    target_cursor.execute(
        "INSERT INTO sync_info (last_sync, source_type, source_id, status) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
        (datetime.now().isoformat(), "import", "initial", "completed")
    )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print("Added sync information")

def main():
    print(f"Starting import from:\n- Notes: {NOTES_DB_PATH}\n- Reminders: {REMINDERS_DB_PATH}")
    print(f"Target DB: {TARGET_DB_PATH}")
    
    start_time = time.time()
    
    # Ensure target database exists
    if not os.path.exists(TARGET_DB_PATH):
        print(f"Error: Target database '{TARGET_DB_PATH}' not found")
        return
    
    # Check if source databases exist
    if not os.path.exists(NOTES_DB_PATH):
        print(f"Error: Notes database '{NOTES_DB_PATH}' not found")
        return
    
    if not os.path.exists(REMINDERS_DB_PATH):
        print(f"Error: Reminders database '{REMINDERS_DB_PATH}' not found")
        return
    
    try:
        # Connect to databases
        notes_conn = sqlite3.connect(NOTES_DB_PATH)
        reminders_conn = sqlite3.connect(REMINDERS_DB_PATH)
        target_conn = sqlite3.connect(TARGET_DB_PATH)
        
        # Enable foreign keys
        target_conn.execute("PRAGMA foreign_keys = ON")
        
        # Import data
        import_accounts(notes_conn, target_conn)
        import_folders(notes_conn, target_conn)
        import_notes(notes_conn, target_conn)
        import_attachments(notes_conn, target_conn)
        
        import_reminder_lists(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminders(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_alerts(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_recurrences(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_attachments(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_participants(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        
        update_sync_info(target_conn)
        
        # Close connections
        notes_conn.close()
        reminders_conn.close()
        target_conn.close()
        
        elapsed_time = time.time() - start_time
        print(f"\nImport completed successfully in {elapsed_time:.2f} seconds")
        
    except sqlite3.Error as e:
        print(f"SQLite error: {e}")
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Error: {e}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

    folders = cursor.fetchall()

            (pk, name or "Unknown Folder", parent_id, account_id, path)
        )

    print(f"Imported {len(folders)} folders")

def import_notes(notes_conn, target_conn):
    """Import notes from Apple Notes to our database"""
    print("Importing notes...")
    
    # Get notes from Notes database
    cursor = notes_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT n.Z_PK, n.ZTITLE, n.ZDATECREATED, n.ZDATEEDITED, 
               b.ZHTMLSTRING, n.ZFOLDER, n.ZUNIVERSALLYUNIQUEID
        FROM ZNOTE n
        LEFT JOIN ZNOTEBODY b ON n.ZBODY = b.Z_PK
    """)
    notes = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for note in notes:
        pk, title, created, edited, content, folder_id, uuid = note
        
        # Convert Apple timestamps to ISO format
        created_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(created)
        updated_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(edited)
        
        # Create metadata JSON for any extra fields we might want to keep
        metadata = json.dumps({"apple_uuid": uuid})
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            """INSERT INTO notes 
               (id, title, created_at, updated_at, content, folder_id, original_id, metadata) 
               VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)""",
            (pk, title or "Untitled Note", created_at, updated_at, 
             content, folder_id, uuid, metadata)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(notes)} notes")

def import_attachments(notes_conn, target_conn):
    """Import attachments from Apple Notes to our database"""
    print("Importing note attachments...")
    
    # Get attachments from Notes database
    cursor = notes_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("SELECT Z_PK, ZNOTE, ZCONTENTID, ZFILEURL FROM ZATTACHMENT")
    attachments = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for attachment in attachments:
        pk, note_id, content_id, file_url = attachment
        
        # Determine filename and type
        filename = extract_filename(file_url)
        file_type = "unknown"
        if filename:
            ext = filename.split('.')[-1].lower() if '.' in filename else ''
            if ext in ['jpg', 'jpeg', 'png', 'gif']:
                file_type = "image"
            elif ext == 'pdf':
                file_type = "pdf"
            elif ext in ['txt', 'md', 'rtf']:
                file_type = "text"
            elif ext in ['mov', 'mp4']:
                file_type = "video"
        
        # For now, we'll just reference the original attachments
        # In a real implementation, we'd extract and save them
        file_path = f"attachments/{content_id}" if content_id else None

            (pk, note_id, content_id, file_type, filename, file_path)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(attachments)} note attachments")

def import_reminder_lists(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder lists from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder lists...")
    
    # Get reminder lists from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()

        SELECT ROWID, title, color, external_id 
        FROM Calendar 
        WHERE Calendar.type = 0
    """)

    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for i, lst in enumerate(lists):
        rowid, title, color, external_id = lst
        
        # Convert color to hex format if needed
        color_hex = f"#{color:06x}" if color else None
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO lists (id, name, color_hex, external_id, position) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, title or "Untitled List", color_hex, external_id, i)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(lists)} reminder lists")

def import_reminders(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminders from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminders...")
    
    # Get reminders from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, summary, description, start_date, end_date, due_date,
               priority, completion_date, creation_date, calendar_id, hidden
        FROM CalendarItem
        WHERE entity_type = 1
    """)
    reminders = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for reminder in reminders:
        (rowid, summary, description, start_date, end_date, due_date,
         priority, completion_date, creation_date, calendar_id, hidden) = reminder
        
        # Convert Apple timestamps to ISO format
        due_date_str = apple_time_to_timestamp(due_date)
        completed_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(completion_date)
        created_at = apple_time_to_timestamp(creation_date)
        start_date_str = apple_time_to_timestamp(start_date)
        
        # Set is_completed based on completion_date
        is_completed = 1 if completion_date else 0
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            """INSERT INTO reminders 
               (id, title, notes, due_date, priority, is_completed, completed_at, 
                created_at, list_id, start_date, is_hidden) 
               VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)""",
            (rowid, summary or "Untitled Reminder", description, due_date_str, 
             priority, is_completed, completed_at, created_at, 
             calendar_id, start_date_str, hidden or 0)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(reminders)} reminders")

def import_reminder_alerts(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder alerts from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder alerts...")
    
    # Get reminder alerts from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, calendaritem_owner_id, fire_date, type
        FROM Alarm
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Alarm.calendaritem_owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    alerts = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for alert in alerts:
        rowid, reminder_id, fire_date, alert_type = alert
        
        # Convert Apple timestamp
        alert_time = apple_time_to_timestamp(fire_date)
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO reminder_alerts (id, reminder_id, alert_time, alert_type) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, reminder_id, alert_time, alert_type)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(alerts)} reminder alerts")

def import_reminder_recurrences(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder recurrences from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder recurrences...")
    
    # Get reminder recurrences from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, owner_id, frequency, interval, end_date_type
        FROM Recurrence
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Recurrence.owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    recurrences = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for recurrence in recurrences:
        rowid, reminder_id, frequency, interval, end_date_type = recurrence
        
        # Map frequency value to text
        freq_map = {
            0: "daily",
            1: "weekly",
            2: "monthly",
            3: "yearly"
        }
        frequency_text = freq_map.get(frequency, "unknown")
        
        # Map end_date_type to text
        end_type_map = {
            0: "never",
            1: "on_date",
            2: "after_count"
        }
        end_type = end_type_map.get(end_date_type, "never")
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            """INSERT INTO reminder_recurrences 
               (id, reminder_id, frequency, interval, end_type) 
               VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)""",
            (rowid, reminder_id, frequency_text, interval or 1, end_type)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(recurrences)} reminder recurrences")

def import_reminder_attachments(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder attachments from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder attachments...")
    
    # Get reminder attachments from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, owner_id, filename
        FROM Attachment
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Attachment.owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    attachments = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for attachment in attachments:
        rowid, reminder_id, filename = attachment
        
        # For now, we'll just reference the filename
        # In a real implementation, we'd extract and save the binary data
        file_path = f"reminder_attachments/{rowid}_{filename}" if filename else None
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO reminder_attachments (id, reminder_id, filename, file_path) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, reminder_id, filename, file_path)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(attachments)} reminder attachments")

def import_reminder_participants(reminders_conn, target_conn):
    """Import reminder participants from Apple Reminders to our database"""
    print("Importing reminder participants...")
    
    # Get reminder participants from Reminders database
    cursor = reminders_conn.cursor()
    cursor.execute("""
        SELECT ROWID, owner_id, type, name, email
        FROM Participant
        JOIN CalendarItem ON Participant.owner_id = CalendarItem.ROWID
        WHERE CalendarItem.entity_type = 1
    """)
    participants = cursor.fetchall()
    
    # Insert into our database
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    for participant in participants:
        rowid, reminder_id, type_id, name, email = participant
        
        # Map participant type to role
        role_map = {
            0: "organizer",
            1: "required",
            2: "optional",
            3: "fyi"
        }
        role = role_map.get(type_id, "unknown")
        
        target_cursor.execute(
            "INSERT INTO reminder_participants (id, reminder_id, name, email, role) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?)",
            (rowid, reminder_id, name, email, role)
        )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print(f"Imported {len(participants)} reminder participants")

def update_sync_info(target_conn):
    """Add sync info record"""
    print("Adding sync information...")
    
    target_cursor = target_conn.cursor()
    target_cursor.execute(
        "INSERT INTO sync_info (last_sync, source_type, source_id, status) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)",
        (datetime.now().isoformat(), "import", "initial", "completed")
    )
    
    target_conn.commit()
    print("Added sync information")

def main():
    print(f"Starting import from:\n- Notes: {NOTES_DB_PATH}\n- Reminders: {REMINDERS_DB_PATH}")
    print(f"Target DB: {TARGET_DB_PATH}")
    
    start_time = time.time()
    
    # Ensure target database exists
    if not os.path.exists(TARGET_DB_PATH):
        print(f"Error: Target database '{TARGET_DB_PATH}' not found")
        return
    
    # Check if source databases exist
    if not os.path.exists(NOTES_DB_PATH):
        print(f"Error: Notes database '{NOTES_DB_PATH}' not found")
        return
    
    if not os.path.exists(REMINDERS_DB_PATH):
        print(f"Error: Reminders database '{REMINDERS_DB_PATH}' not found")
        return
    
    try:
        # Connect to databases
        notes_conn = sqlite3.connect(NOTES_DB_PATH)
        reminders_conn = sqlite3.connect(REMINDERS_DB_PATH)
        target_conn = sqlite3.connect(TARGET_DB_PATH)
        
        # Enable foreign keys
        target_conn.execute("PRAGMA foreign_keys = ON")
        
        # Import data
        import_accounts(notes_conn, target_conn)
        import_folders(notes_conn, target_conn)
        import_notes(notes_conn, target_conn)
        import_attachments(notes_conn, target_conn)
        
        import_reminder_lists(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminders(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_alerts(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_recurrences(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_attachments(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        import_reminder_participants(reminders_conn, target_conn)
        
        update_sync_info(target_conn)
        
        # Close connections
        notes_conn.close()
        reminders_conn.close()
        target_conn.close()
        
        elapsed_time = time.time() - start_time
        print(f"\nImport completed successfully in {elapsed_time:.2f} seconds")
        
    except sqlite3.Error as e:
        print(f"SQLite error: {e}")
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Error: {e}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
